header_title:
Test your urine
 regularly at home.
result_grade_2: '✓ If levels remain consistently high, medical examination is recommended.
guide1: ✓ Shows the test results from the last 7 days.
guide2: ✓ The most recent data is displayed from left to right.
guide3: ✓ When tested multiple times a day, the latest data is displayed.
trans_blood: Q.How has my occult blood level changed?
trans_bilirubin: Q.How has my bilirubin level changed?
trans_urobilnogen: Q.How has my urobilinogen level changed?
trans_ketones: Q.How has my ketones level changed?
trans_protein: Q.How has my protein level changed?
trans_nitrate: Q.How has my nitrite level changed?
trans_glucosuria: Q.How has my glucose level changed?
trans_ph: Q.How has my pH level changed?
trans_gravity: Q.How has my specific gravity level changed?
trans_leukocytes: Q.How has my leukocytes level changed?
trans_vitamins: Q.How has my vitamin C level changed?
desc_blood:
Blood in urine can indicate issues with the kidneys, bladder, or urinary tract. If the result shows Risk or Critical, consult a veterinarian.
Temporary results may appear after intense exercise, but usually return to normal.
desc_bilirubin: Bilirubin in urine may suggest liver or blood disorders, and is an important indicator of liver function, especially in dogs. If the result remains consistently positive, consult a veterinarian for a diagnosis.
desc_urobilnogen: A substance excreted in urine after bilirubin is recycled in the intestine. High levels may indicate infections, cirrhosis, or liver cancer. If the result is Critical, a veterinary check-up is recommended.
desc_ketones: Produced during fat metabolism and excreted in urine. The presence of ketones may be associated with diabetes, starvation, or a high-fat, low-carb diet. A Risk or Critical result indicates the need forfurther testing.
desc_protein: Protein in urine can indicate kidney filtration issues. If the urine appears foamy, proteinuria (protein in urine) is suspected, which may be linked to kidney or systemic diseases. Due to pH sensitivity, further testing may be necessary.
desc_nitrate: Appears in urine during bacterial infections. Any result other than Normal result indicates a high likelihood of bacterial presence. For optimal results, test the first urine of the day.
desc_glucosuria: Normally not found in urine but may appear in cases of diabetes or kidney issues. If glucose is present, diabetes or metabolic disorders may be suspected. A Risk or Critical result indicates a need for a veterinary visit.
desc_ph:
Measures the acidity of urine.
The normal pH range is 6-7.5.
Abnormal pH can be affected by diet, urinary tract infections, or systemic acid-base balance.
Optimal pH for dogs: 7.0-7.5 for
cats: 6.3-6.6.
desc_gravity:
Measures urine concentration to assess kidney function. Abnormal specific gravity may suggest dehydration or impaired kidney function. 1.000 and 1.070 results warrant caution.
Cats: Normal range 1.035-1.060
Dogs: Normal range 1.015-1.045
desc_leukocytes:
Increase during bacterial
infections of the kidneys, urinary tract, or prostate. A Risk or Critical result suggests possible bacterial infection and requires further diagnostic testing.
Bacterial infection can be confirmed alongside the nitrite result. Even if leukocyte levels are low, a pink nitrite result suggests possible infection.
desc_vitamins: High levels of ascorbic acid may affect test results for glucose, blood, bilirubin, and nitrite. A dark yellow result visually on the strip indicates the need for caution.
adjText1: Abnormal results for the given parameter may indicate the following diseases:
adjEmptyText1: The analysis results for the given parameter shows that
disease_grade: ✓ You can check disease information by parameter.
tract_grade_1: ✓ Urinary tract infection level is low.'
tract_grade_2: ✓ Urinary tract infection detected, please also check for alkalinuria.'
logout_content: Are you sure you want to log out?
related_blood: Occult blood, acute nephritis, chronic nephritis, anemia, urinary tract infection, etc.
related_bilirubin: Hepatitis, gallstones, pancreatitis, bile duct obstruction, etc.
related_urobilnogen: Acute nephritis, chronic nephritis, anemia, urinary tract infection, etc.
related_ketones: Hepatitis, gallstones, pancreatitis, bile duct obstruction, etc.
related_ph: Acidic: renal tuberculosis, severe diabetes, nephritis, alcohol poisoning, etc. Alkaline: urinary tract infections, kidney stones, hyperventilation, etc.
related_gravity: Low specific gravity: renal failure, pyelonephritis High specific gravity: diabetes, dehydration, diarrhea, etc.
related_leukocytes: Pyelonephritis, cystitis, urinary stones, renal tuberculosis, etc.
related_vitamins: Excessive vitamin C can lead to errors in the measurement of glucose, protein, and alkaline urine.
kidneys_symptoms:
• Decreased or increased urine output
• Abdominal or lower back pain
• Symptoms such as headache, high blood pressure, or difficulty breathing
• Numbness in hands and feet or muscle cramps
kidneys_guide:
• Diabetes: Can occur when high blood sugar damages the blood vessels and tissues of the kidneys.
• Hypertension: Prolonged high blood pressure can damage the blood vessels in the kidneys, leading to decreased kidney function.
• Chronic Nephritis: Long-term inflammation of the kidneys that can damage kidney tissue and impair function.
• Complications from other diseases: Various conditions, such as metabolic disorders, autoimmune diseases, hypothyroidism, and chronic illnesses, can lead to reduced kidney function.
bladder_symptoms:
• Frequent urge to urinate
• Sudden feeling of needing to urinate
• Pain or burning sensation while urinating
• Accompanied by fever
bladder_guide:
• Drink plenty of fluids
• Frequently empty the bladder and maintain proper toilet habits
pancreas_symptoms:
• Experience severe, persistent pain starting in the upper abdomen that may radiate to the back or lower abdomen
• Gastrointestinal symptoms such as vomiting, indigestion, and nausea
• Loss of appetite and weight loss consult a healthcare provider immediately for treatment.
pancreas_guide:
• Walk slowly on flat ground for about 20-30 minutes daily
• Practice deep breathing exercises while sitting comfortably
anemia_symptoms:
• General symptoms: fatigue, lethargy, and dizziness
• Skin symptoms: paleness, cheilitis, glossitis may be observed
• Digestive issues: loss of appetite, indigestion
• Genitourinary issues: menstrual irregularities
anemia_guide:
• Low-intensity aerobic exercises
• Simple yoga poses for 15-20 minutes daily
• Consume fruits rich in vitamin C
• Include dairy products like yogurt and cheese that contain vitamin B12
diabetes_symptoms:
• Frequent urination
• Increased thirst
• Unstable or suddenly increased appetite
• Slow healing of wounds or injuries
diabetes_guide:
• Walk slowly on flat ground for about 30 minutes daily
• Stretch major muscle groups gently for 10 minutes in the morning or evening
nephritis_symptoms:
• Symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, indigestion, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, and muscle cramps
• Increased or decreased urine output
• Slow healing of wounds or injuries
nephritis_guide:
• Walking as a low-intensity aerobic exercise helps maintain cardiovascular health and manage weight
• Deep breathing exercises reduce stress and promote relaxation
polycysticnephritis_symptoms:
• Abdominal or kidney pain
• Hematuria (blood in urine)
• High blood pressure
• Decreased kidney function
• Abdominal bloating
polycysticnephritis_guide:
• Maintain a healthy diet: Reduce sodium intake and ensure adequate hydration
• Exercise moderately: Regular exercise is important for health, but avoid excessive strain
• Regular check-ups: Periodically monitor kidney function and blood pressure
acutehepatitis_symptoms:
• Loss of appetite: Caused by cytokines or other chemicals released from the infected liver.
• Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain
• Pruritus: Occurs when there is bile obstruction, leading to bile salts accumulation.
• Fatigue
• Jaundice: Accumulation of bilirubin in tissues initially seen in the sclera of the eyes and later in the skin and urine, resulting in dark brown or yellowish coloration.
acutehepatitis_guide:
• Consume plenty of fresh fruits and vegetables
• Recommended protein intake
• Avoid raw foods
• Recommend consuming 330-400g of carbohydrates
hyperthyroidism_symptoms:
• Difficulty tolerating heat and excessive sweating
• Increased appetite with weight loss
• Rapid depletion of energy and fatigue
• Excessive sweating and rapid heartbeat
• Increased sensitivity and anxiety
• Women may face menstrual irregularities or increased risk of infertility
hyperthyroidism_guide:
• Prioritize hospital diagnosis and treatment
• Recommend consumption of cabbage, broccoli, kale, radishes, and cauliflower
hepatitis_symptoms:
• Loss of appetite
• Generalized body aches
• Vomiting
• Pain in the upper right abdomen (where the liver is located)
• Dark-colored urine
• Jaundice in about 70% of cases (yellowing of skin and eyes)
hepatitis_guide:
• Consume plenty of fresh fruits and vegetables
• Recommended protein intake
• Avoid raw foods
• Recommend consuming 330-400g of carbohydrates
kidneydisease_symptoms:
• Decreased appetite
• Difficulty sleeping
• General fatigue
• Dry skin
• Frequent nighttime urination
• Foamy urine
• Swelling around the eyes
• Swelling in the feet and ankles
kidneydisease_guide:
• Hydration: It is important to consume more than 2L of water daily.
• Fruit and vegetable intake: Include strawberries, watermelon, carrots, pineapple, grapes, apples, and broccoli.
• Whole grains: When cooking rice, it is recommended to include brown rice, oats, barley, and beans.
health_symptoms: Most results were negative, and regular monitoring and check-ups are recommended.
health_guide:
1) Healthy eating habits: Reduce sodium intake and ensure adequate hydration. Consuming plenty of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains is also important.
2) Moderate exercise: Maintain health with regular exercise but avoid excessive strain.
3) Regular check-ups: Periodically monitor how kidney function changes and keep track of blood pressure.
